Project.title: Responsive multimodal interface for in-vehicle interactions
Project.abstract:
This study aims to develop a ‘Responsive Multimodal Interface’ enhancing the safety and usability of in-vehicle interactions. This involves researching a technology that recognizes the characteristics of passengers and functions performed in autonomous vehicles, and presents suitable modalities (interaction methods for input and output for task execution) to allow users to achieve their desired objectives. The goal of this research is to improve the stability and usability of in-vehicle interfaces for autonomous vehicle passengers by designing a technology that encourages interaction based on the characteristics and goals of passengers.
'Responsive Multimodal Interface’ consists of
1) 'Modality Selection Technology,' which determines the optimal interaction method based on passenger characteristics and target functions, and
2) 'Affordance Design Technology,' which guides passengers to interact through the selected modality.

Project.title: Digital Transformation of Small and Medium Manufacturers
Interface Optimization Study for Autonomous Driving UX
Project.abstract: Improvement of voice and visual interfaces by discovering problems with VUI use of current AVNT vehicles. Guidelines for Voice UI and Visual UI of Infotainment System.

Project.title: Perceived Image Quality of Smartphone Camera
Project.abstract: This study aims to investigate the relationship between perceptual image quality, affective image quality, and user preference for smartphone camera photos. A semantic scale consisting of four perceptual (‘color’, ‘exposure’, ‘noise’, ‘texture’) image qualities and eight affective (‘trendy’, ‘vivid’, ‘natural’, ‘bold’, ‘soft’, ‘warm’, ‘blueish’, ‘yellowish’) image qualities were defined through literature review and text-mining. Participants evaluated preferences, perceptual quality, and affective quality for the photos displayed on smartphones. The results of the multiple linear regression analysis showed that all perceptual qualities are significant determinants of preference. In affective qualities, ‘trendy’, ‘vivid’, ‘natural’, ‘bold’, and ‘yellowish’ were predictors of user preferences. Finally, ‘color’, ‘exposure’, and ‘texture’ had positive correlations with ‘trendy’, ‘vivid’, ‘natural’, and ‘bold’. This study presented two perspectives that could help improve users' preferences for smartphone photos. Additionally, the user survey method used in this study could make it efficient to investigate the preference for smartphone photos.

Project.title: Emotional Intelligence Technology to Infer Human Emotion and Carry-on Dialogue Accordingly
Project.abstract:
Development of a voice-based psychological counseling agent that responds to the psychological state of its user
●Analyzed Human–AI interaction and create a customer journey map
●Analyzed the corpus that occurs when interacting with an AI to analyze user needs
●Designed user-centered text and voice based psychological counseling agent operation methods
●Designed psychological counseling response framework suitable for AI to relieve the psychological state of the user
●Improved psychological state of the user and secured expertise of the psychological counseling agent through user experiments
●Consulted 2021 development of a psychological counseling chat-bot of ‘Seoul Mental Health Welfare Center’ based on the research associated with the project

Project.title: Development of a Digital Transformation Maturity Model
Evaluation of Usability of Smartphone (A Study on the Proper Form Factor Level in Mobile Environment)
Project.abstract:
Diagnose mobile life appropriateness of 1) main form factor (width, bottom bezel) and 2) new design trend (18: 9 aspect ratio, edge display) applied to smartphone devices (5.0 - 5.7 inch) from human factors point of view. Derive appropriate design level and guidelines for smartphone form factor for stable one-handed operation.
●Coordinated user performance comparison experiment based on the Fit’s law for different smartphone screen ratios
●Coordinated user performance comparison experiment in relation to smartphone usage environment (e.g. walking, sitting)
●Coordinated user performance comparison experiment in relation to curvatures (e.g. edge, flat) of smartphone screens.
